headline.main: AFFAIRS ON THIS UPPER POTOMAC.; Movements of the Army Rebel Knowledge of our Movements.Mails for the Soldiers The Weather Conditionof the Wounded Incidents, &c. THE WOUNDED THE SINKING OF THE SCOW, AND OTHER INTERESTING PARTICULARS. A DESERTER'S REPORT OF THE NUMBER OF REBELS ENGAGED INCIDENTS AND SCENES OF THE FIGHT MISCELLANEOUS MATTERS.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hearing heavy cannonading in the direction of Edwards' Ferry, this morning, I started from Camp Observation, near the Monocacy, to ascertain and report what was going on. Having reached this camp, I learned that all was quiet at Edwards' Ferry, and that all our troops have fallen back from the river in this vicinity, and are proceeding, apparently, towards Point of Rocks. The firing was only the practicing...

headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; The Condition of Affairs at Washington Unchanged. More About the Late Fight at Ball's Bluff. Complete Lists of the Killed and Wounded. HEAVY LOSS OF THE REBELS HIGHLY IMPORTANT FROM MISSOURI. The Advance of Gen. Fremont to Springfield. The Daring Charge of Fremont's Body Guard. Uncertainty as to the Plans of Price. Two Successful Skirmishes in Kentucky. Delay in the Departure of the Great Naval Expedition. ANOTHER GRAND REVIEW. CONTROVERSY BETWEEN THE FRIENDS OF BAKER AND STONE. IMPATIENT OF DELAY. CHARACTER OF THE FOREIGN ADVICES. GARIBALDI AND THE REBELLION. THE CASES OF NORTHERN MERCHANTS. WILL LAGER BIER INTOXICATE? NARROW ESCAPE OF COL. BETJE. SENATOR WILSON AND THE COLONELCY OF THE MASSACHUSETTS TWENTY-SECOND. DRILLING MEN-OF-WARS MEN. WATCHING THE REBEL STEAMER PAGE. BURSTING OF A PARROTT GUN. THE RIGHT WING QUIET. THE HARRIS LIGHT CAVALRY MADE REGULARS. A REGIMENT IN DELAWARE. CAPT. SHIELDS TO BE RELEASED. GOING HOME. GEN. SCOTT'S HEALTH.

docs.snippet: The Enquirer gives a list of the shares of stock in the Richmond and Petersburgh Railroad, sequestered under the confiscation act of Congress. The total number is 747. That paper adds: All of the shareholders enumerated are Philadelphians, with the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enquirer gives a list of the shares of stock in the Richmond and Petersburgh Railroad, sequestered under the confiscation act of Congress. The total number is 747. That paper adds: All of the shareholders enumerated are Philadelphians, with the exception of Mrs. ELLIES, who resides in the interior of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. VAN COURTLANDT, who is a resident of New-York. The entire number of shares constituting the capital stock of the company is 9,866...
